part.name: first_day
part.narration: Yuki looks around. Signs are in Japanese. Voices are in Japanese. People are in Japanese. JJ has a front seat. The teacher raises her hand.
part.line: Class, welcome our new student, Yuki—
part.narration: The teacher pauses and glances at Yuki. She looks back at the paper. She again looks at Yuki—
part.line: Takeshi.
Alright, take a seat.
part.narration: The Player walks Yuki to the back of the classroom. Every seat looks suspicious upon nearing it.To which seat does Yuki belong? There are ten in the back of the classroom, all of them not exclusively for Burakumin or Brazilians, but for that united-yet-fallen sort of lost children. Foreigners. Newcomers. Those unfamiliar with the village, malleable, longing for proper assimilation at the hands of anyone who dare provide it. Yuki sits. Two children heckle her.
part.line: So what part of Japan are you from?
France.
And here I thought all blondes came from America.
I hear our cartoons are pretty popular in France.
Good for the cartoons.
Did you remember to do the homework?

choice.line: For today, you were supposed to draw a picture and tell the class about someone that inspires you.
Since even our foreign student had a weekend's advance, I expect you all did the assignment.
After all, your entire participation grade depends on it.

part.line: So we may have a proper introduction to them, we'll have our new students present first.
Jacques!
part.narration: The class claps for the new student.
part.line: Calm down, everyone. I haven't even gotten to the good part yet!
part.narration: Yuki gasps. JJ takes out a crayon drawing of Asami.
part.line: This is my mom.
She's a musician.
She played a really important show at harughlegargle blahblah sphinxterstankle.
part.narration: Yuki springs up and flings the desk astray.
part.line: What! When did you learn Japanese?
part.narration: Everyone hushes Yuki.If the Player doesn't make Yuki sit, someone else will.The teacher sits back and waves her hand.
part.line: Jacques, continue.
She inspires me because hurkadurka derpaderp hurr durr genuflectacatamaran.
part.narration: With each phrase of the tongue, Yuki's heart beats faster. She clasps her temples. She needs to get away from this. She needs to leave. She needs an excuse! The teacher continues.
part.line: You mean, your mom is Dr. Takeshi, ljfoijoiejoaijwofiajwogijawoiegj?
mahagbomanring hopralofeeblenfro.
part.narration: Yuki raises her hand. She sweats, shakes, eyes fixed on the exit. The teacher points at her.
part.line: Oh shizzle ameliabedelia dynamite?

choice.line: I need to go to the bathroom!
choice.narration: Yuki dashes and hits the teacher on the way to the door closest to the bathroom.

choice.line: I need to get a drink!
choice.narration: Yuki dashes and trips over a desk on the way to the door closest to the water fountain.

part.narration: A self-conscious moment. Until she goes back to class, the camera remains extremely close to Yuki and out of the player's control. Action buttons shuffle around. The Main Action changes to rocking back and forth.Wherever she is, Yuki drops into fetal position. She begins to whisper to herself.
part.line: In the womb, there were no languages.
I'm stupid.
part.narration: Yuki whispers more frantically.
part.line: Japanese language characters cover a larger range of the Unicode character space.
The language is more complex. Only smart people can speak it.
JJ can speak it. The kids can speak it. I can't.
part.narration: The Administrator sees Yuki. He grimaces, grabs her by the arm, and drags her towards the classroom. Yuki is compliant. She can hear the sound of cheering from outside.
part.line: Japanese people are smarter than me.
Japanese people don't need dye to be black and beautiful.
"Influence is the marriage of intelligence and appearance."
part.narration: Yuki slows down.
part.line: Japanese people are better than me.
part.narration: The Administrator throws Yuki back into the classroom. She trips and falls. Except JJ, everyone laughs. The Administrator silences them.
part.line: Damn misfit kid. Found her skipping class.
part.narration: The Administrator points at Yuki.
part.line: You're making your brother look bad.
part.narration: The Administrator exits. As if nothing happened, the teacher continues.
part.line: Yuki, your turn to present.
part.narration: It's cold outside. The windows are open. Someone should close them. Hopefully, the coffee is still warm. The teacher sits down and has a cup. Did anyone watch last week's episode of Pokémon? Everyone chats amongst each other. Yuki looks down.
part.line: Present, huh?
part.narration: The teacher waves her hand while taking a sip.
part.line: Present the homework.
Homework, huh?
You did read the paper I gave you, right?
part.narration: The teacher puts a piece of paper on the desk. Yuki picks it up and has a look.The player is urged to pick it up and take a look. Yuki urges the player to zoom in. The letters on the paper shift around. Constant failing Vision texts appear. The kid has a lot of symbols to learn.
part.line: I can't read.
part.narration: The teacher face-palms. The students guffaw.
part.line: What kind of fifth grader can't read?
part.narration: The teacher silences the class.
part.line: Yuki, draw the person who inspires you on that chalkboard.
part.narration: The teacher points at the board and throws Yuki a piece of chalk. The player has to pick it up and go to the chalkboard to continue drawing. She begins to draw. The chalk runs out. The teacher throws her another piece. It runs out. Students begin to take pieces of chalk from nooks and crannies of the room and toss it at Yuki. The chalk is thrown in random places. Some pieces bounce off of Yuki. The Player is to retrieve them and return to the board.Yuki keeps drawing. She keeps running out. She draws. She runs out. She draws. She runs out. She sighs. Covered in chalk, Yuki stands tall and presents her source of inspiration:
part.line: Sonic the Hedgehog.
part.narration: The teacher facepalms. The students guffaw.
part.line: I said "person." Like family, or friends, or...
He's not even on playstation!
Or any good games.
I can't let an illiterate child tarnish my reputation...
Better dump her on the remedial teachers.
This is not my classroom.
part.narration: Yuki gave up. Years passed. Every year, her hair was further in disarray. Every year, her work became sloppier. Every year, she broke down at least once in every classroom. She barely passed her remedial classes. She barely passed anything.The Player can walk around. There are constant sudden-cuts from classroom to classroom, a year between each. In each cut, Yuki holds a failed paper. In each cut, Yuki looks worse off.
